reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7353, 'name': 'Kevin Carter', 'email': 'kevin@cloudnull.com', 'username': 'cloudnull'}, {'_account_id': 11090, 'name': 'Sergii Golovatiuk', 'email': 'sgolovat@redhat.com', 'username': 'holser'}, {'_account_id': 16515, 'name': 'mbu', 'email': 'mat.bultel@gmail.com', 'username': 'matbu'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24162, 'name': 'Sorin Sbârnea', 'display_name': 'zbr', 'email': 'ssbarnea@redhat.com', 'username': 'ssbarnea', 'status': 'do not feed the troll 🥕'}, {'_account_id': 27427, 'name': 'David Peacock', 'email': 'dpeacock@redhat.com', 'username': 'davidjpeacock'}, {'_account_id': 28223, 'name': 'Cedric Jeanneret', 'display_name': 'cjeanner (Tengu)', 'email': 'cjeanner@redhat.com', 'username': 'cjeanner'}, {'_account_id': 32926, 'name': 'Jiri Podivin', 'display_name': 'jpodivin', 'email': 'jpodivin@redhat.com', 'username': 'jpodivin'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-19 14:09:49.000000000', 'message': "Introduce tox-ansible to tripleo-validations

This patch adds basic configuration for tox-ansible[1].

Tox-ansible is a plugin for tox which auto-generates tox environments
for running quality assurance tools like ansible-test or molecule. This
tool is rather tightly integrated for the official Molecule testing tool
that integrates with Ansible.

At first, it will allow us to list very quickly all the Ansible Molecule
tests for each roles with their scenario(s):

Example:

    $ tox -l
    ...
    roles-ceph-ceph-ansible-installed
    roles-ceph-default
    roles-check_kernel_version-default
    roles-check_network_gateway-default
    roles-check_rhsm_version-default
    roles-check_rhsm_version-rhsm_mismatch
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-config_OK
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-default
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-deprecated_drivers
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-deprecated_params
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-required_missing
    ...

However, we won't be able to execute them as it for now without to make
some small manual modifications in the molecule.yml file first before to
execute them. This will be covered as soon as possible in a following-patch.

[1] - https://github.com/ansible-community/tox-ansible

Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ia1606db814f37a11e48508139b90cdd43c083f6b
"}]
commit_message:
Introduce tox-ansible to tripleo-validations

This patch adds basic configuration for tox-ansible[1].

Tox-ansible is a plugin for tox which auto-generates tox environments
for running quality assurance tools like ansible-test or molecule. This
tool is rather tightly integrated for the official Molecule testing tool
that integrates with Ansible.

At first, it will allow us to list very quickly all the Ansible Molecule
tests for each roles with their scenario(s):

Example:

    $ tox -l
    ...
    roles-ceph-ceph-ansible-installed
    roles-ceph-default
    roles-check_kernel_version-default
    roles-check_network_gateway-default
    roles-check_rhsm_version-default
    roles-check_rhsm_version-rhsm_mismatch
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-config_OK
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-default
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-deprecated_drivers
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-deprecated_params
    roles-check_undercloud_conf-required_missing
    ...

However, we won't be able to execute them as it for now without to make
some small manual modifications in the molecule.yml file first before to
execute them. This will be covered as soon as possible in a following-patch.

[1] - https://github.com/ansible-community/tox-ansible

Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ia1606db814f37a11e48508139b90cdd43c083f6b

commit_message:
Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

commit_message:
Remove references to unsupported operating systems

All references to Gentoo, SUSE, Debian stretch and Centos-7  are removed.
Conditional tasks, ternary operators and variables are simplified where possible
OS specific variables files are generalised where possible

Change-Id: I8ccd8ef5cbb4a29b782418ffa33e635962f0941e

messages: [{'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2021-03-16 12:21:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2021-03-16 15:25:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2021-03-18 02:55:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:\n\npleaselookagain'}]

[{'created': '2021-03-16 12:21:21.000000000', 'message': 'Add support oslo_messaging_rabbit configs

Allow set `kombu_missing_consumer_retry_timeout` from oslo_messaging_rabbit
through environment variable `KOMBU_MISSING_CONSUMER_RETRY_TIMEOUT`.

Allow set `rpc_conn_pool_size` from oslo_messaging_rabbit
through environment variable `RPC_CONN_POOL_SIZE`.

Change-Id: Iad8e384260ed1a566a48fbc32b0ae274cb3813b1
'}, {'created': '2021-03-16 15:25:24.000000000', 'message': 'Add support oslo_messaging_rabbit configs

Allow set `kombu_missing_consumer_retry_timeout` from oslo_messaging_rabbit
through environment variable `KOMBU_MISSING_CONSUMER_RETRY_TIMEOUT`.

Allow set `rpc_conn_pool_size` from oslo_messaging_rabbit
through environment variable `RPC_CONN_POOL_SIZE`.

Change-Id: Iad8e384260ed1a566a48fbc32b0ae274cb3813b1
'}]
commit_message:
Add support oslo_messaging_rabbit configs

Allow set `kombu_missing_consumer_retry_timeout` from oslo_messaging_rabbit
through environment variable `KOMBU_MISSING_CONSUMER_RETRY_TIMEOUT`.

Allow set `rpc_conn_pool_size` from oslo_messaging_rabbit
through environment variable `RPC_CONN_POOL_SIZE`.

Change-Id: Iad8e384260ed1a566a48fbc32b0ae274cb3813b1

subject: Update master for stable/wallaby
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-22 10:04:31.000000000', 'message': 'Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: Iee849a3edc463b204686a6b95ae1f83bc5eefcd2
'}]
commit_message:
Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: Iee849a3edc463b204686a6b95ae1f83bc5eefcd2

commit_message:
Don't fail integration tests if browser log couldn't be retrieved

Firefox will throw an "HTTP method not allowed" error randomly when
trying to retrieve the browser log. This change will prevent the
selenium test from failing when that happens, and instead logs
the exact exception that happened as the content of that log.

Change-Id: I3384c3cfdf87f475bf62b2df6b895569723eb187

commit_message:
Fix lower constraints

This patch updates lower-constraints.txt to eliminate contradictions.

keystoneauth1 lower constraint has to be bumped in requirements.txt as
another dependency, openstacksdk 0.15.0 depends on keystoneauth1>=3.8.0

dogpile.cache version bumped to 0.6.5 as older version had 'async' as
variable name which gives SyntaxError from py37.

Change-Id: I31464518cb7f76c0fa5275a4ef52b2a6b634cfa3

[{'created': '2021-03-20 09:08:35.000000000', 'message': "Set proper OVS_SYSCONFDIR for the job wher OVS is compiled

Devstack's patch [1] introduced new variable OVS_SYSCONFDIR which by
default points to the /etc/openvswitch directory. But in case of the
jobs where OVS is installed from source there is no such directory and
/usr/local/etc/openvswitch should be used instead.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/779991

Change-Id: I240d0df197e89224c2447625130f02d640116ba1
Related-Bug: #1918656
"}]
commit_message:
Set proper OVS_SYSCONFDIR for the job wher OVS is compiled

Devstack's patch [1] introduced new variable OVS_SYSCONFDIR which by
default points to the /etc/openvswitch directory. But in case of the
jobs where OVS is installed from source there is no such directory and
/usr/local/etc/openvswitch should be used instead.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/779991

Change-Id: I240d0df197e89224c2447625130f02d640116ba1
Related-Bug: #1918656

subject: Relax some API policy rules to make them available for project admins
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 841, 'name': 'Akihiro Motoki', 'email': 'amotoki@gmail.com', 'username': 'amotoki'}, {'_account_id': 8313, 'name': 'Lajos Katona', 'email': 'katonalala@gmail.com', 'username': 'elajkat'}, {'_account_id': 9845, 'name': 'Arista CI', 'email': 'arista-openstack-test@aristanetworks.com', 'username': 'arista-test', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 9954, 'name': 'Lance Bragstad', 'username': 'lbragstad', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 11975, 'name': 'Slawek Kaplonski', 'email': 'skaplons@redhat.com', 'username': 'slaweq'}, {'_account_id': 16688, 'name': 'Rodolfo Alonso', 'email': 'ralonsoh@redhat.com', 'username': 'rodolfo-alonso-hernandez'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

[{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-16 21:13:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-03-16 21:17:39.000000000', 'content': 'Topic bp/secure-rbac-roles removed'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-03-16 21:17:44.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to secure-rbac'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-17 10:07:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Review-Priority+2'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-17 11:04:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2021-03-17 11:57:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2021-03-18 07:29:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Have to wait for https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/780802'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-18 07:55:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2021-03-18 08:27:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

Some related questions'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-18 09:07:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-18 09:08:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2021-03-18 09:23:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

While I understand the motivation of this change, I concerns this change.
Once we migrated the system-scope world, a project admin is considered as a persona who can view and modify data only within the project. They do not know resource usage outside of the project. However, we allow a project admin for example to specify a segment ID for a provider network. This apparently requires a coordination with an infrastructure team like a network team managing network switches. Considering this point, this change assumes a project admin is part of system operators.

I understand this requires many changes in operations (like command lines) described in the commit message, so it is acceptable for me as a transitional workaround, but I don't think we should keep this forever. What do you think about the final plan?"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2021-03-18 09:36:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I read the meeting log (I failed to join it....), but it is not clear whether it is transient or permanent. I think the meaning of "admin" role will be changed before and after the introduction of the system scope. In the old world without system-scope, operators need to use "admin" role as system admin, but in the system scope world "system-scope=all" does this (so-called) role and a project "admin" will be considered just as a part of the project. Any roles of a project does not / cannot known details of the underlying infrastructure they use. Thus, I wonder this is to mitigate the pain of the migration or not.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-18 10:47:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> I read the meeting log (I failed to join it....), but it is not clear whether it is transient or permanent. I think the meaning of "admin" role will be changed before and after the introduction of the system scope. In the old world without system-scope, operators need to use "admin" role as system admin, but in the system scope world "system-scope=all" does this (so-called) role and a project "admin" will be considered just as a part of the project. Any roles of a project does not / cannot known details of the underlying infrastructure they use. Thus, I wonder this is to mitigate the pain of the migration or not.

I totally agree with Your point. Those should be system scope things only. But I though that maybe we can change those defaults in the next release.
Or TBH more I think about it now, more I'm tend to abandon that patch and simply mention how it works in the release notes. Basically by default we are still using old rules so old behaviour will work. To enable those more secure roles, neutron's config has to be changed so it's kind of opt-in into the new behavior and if so, operator should be aware of what they are enabling.
So I can either abandon this patch now, or I will add TODO notes to remove that PROJECT_ADMIN from some those rules. Wdyt?'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-18 14:48:49.000000000', 'content': 'Topic bp/secure-rbac-roles removed'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-18 14:49:01.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to secure-rbac'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2021-03-19 07:20:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

recheck
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/780802 is merged now'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-19 07:45:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2021-03-19 17:43:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I totally agree with Your point. Those should be system scope things only. But I though that maybe we can change those defaults in the next release.
> Or TBH more I think about it now, more I'm tend to abandon that patch and simply mention how it works in the release notes. Basically by default we are still using old rules so old behaviour will work. To enable those more secure roles, neutron's config has to be changed so it's kind of opt-in into the new behavior and if so, operator should be aware of what they are enabling.
> So I can either abandon this patch now, or I will add TODO notes to remove that PROJECT_ADMIN from some those rules. Wdyt?

My current vote is not to relax rules as this change proposes.

You see a good point. The new secure RBAC role mechanism is opt-in. By default neutron's behavior is not changed and the existing operation workflows can be used as is. I think we can collect differences when we switch to the system-scope world in our documentation or somewhere. Operators who would like to switch to the system-scope world, they can check such differences.

In addition, there is an ongoing discussions on how users with system-scoped token interact with resources in a project. It was mentioned by a mailing list post by lbragstad [1][2]. The original discussion happens from nova, but I think the issue raised in this change is one of the examples discussed in the thread. I think we can follow the discussion and adjust the behavior in neutron in Xena.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-March/021131.html
[2] https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/consuming-system-scope"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2021-03-19 17:44:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2021-03-22 08:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-22 10:13:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: -Review-Priority

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> > I totally agree with Your point. Those should be system scope things only. But I though that maybe we can change those defaults in the next release.
> > Or TBH more I think about it now, more I'm tend to abandon that patch and simply mention how it works in the release notes. Basically by default we are still using old rules so old behaviour will work. To enable those more secure roles, neutron's config has to be changed so it's kind of opt-in into the new behavior and if so, operator should be aware of what they are enabling.
> > So I can either abandon this patch now, or I will add TODO notes to remove that PROJECT_ADMIN from some those rules. Wdyt?
> 
> My current vote is not to relax rules as this change proposes.
> 
> You see a good point. The new secure RBAC role mechanism is opt-in. By default neutron's behavior is not changed and the existing operation workflows can be used as is. I think we can collect differences when we switch to the system-scope world in our documentation or somewhere. Operators who would like to switch to the system-scope world, they can check such differences.
> 
> In addition, there is an ongoing discussions on how users with system-scoped token interact with resources in a project. It was mentioned by a mailing list post by lbragstad [1][2]. The original discussion happens from nova, but I think the issue raised in this change is one of the examples discussed in the thread. I think we can follow the discussion and adjust the behavior in neutron in Xena.
> 
> [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-March/021131.html
> [2] https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/consuming-system-scope

Thx for Your comment. I'm abandoning this patch now."}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-03-22 10:14:03.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

We decided to not relax those new policies.'}]

commit_message:
Relax some API policy rules to make them available for project admins

As part of the migration to the new secure-rbac roles and personas we
proposed new policy rules for our API.
For some of the calls, like e.g. creation of the provider networks with
specified physical network we originally made it to be available only
for the SYSTEM_ADMIN user as that is really SYSTEM specific thing.
But that would mean that such SYSTEM_ADMIN user would always need to
specify project_id to create such resource. And that would be
significant change comparing to the old behaviour with "admin" user.

So this patch relax a bit those new policies to make them available also
for PROJECT_ADMIN users to mimic old behaviour, at least for now.

Change-Id: I0580bbabd1d9af7a5f2c60b63c42a977d73eeefe

subject: Support uploading image from data and stdin
messages: [{'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2021-03-09 07:35:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2021-03-22 09:56:01.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-09 07:35:20.000000000', 'message': 'Support uploading image from data and stdin

It might be useful to upload image from stdin. Disadvantage is, that it
is not possible to calculate checksums and this will prohibit threaded
image upload when using swift and tasks.
Additionally fix checksum validation during image creation - when
create_image is not called through cloud layer - the result might be
different, when checksums of existing image match (due to call and
return cloud.get_image). Fixing this requires also completing image v1
(proper find). Yeah, lots of tests are affected by that change.

Required-by: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650374
Change-Id: I709d8b48cb7867fd806e2f19781bb84739363843
(cherry picked from commit 63fe02bf770b47d6001ad802be851765f1d1b862)
'}]
commit_message:
Support uploading image from data and stdin

It might be useful to upload image from stdin. Disadvantage is, that it
is not possible to calculate checksums and this will prohibit threaded
image upload when using swift and tasks.
Additionally fix checksum validation during image creation - when
create_image is not called through cloud layer - the result might be
different, when checksums of existing image match (due to call and
return cloud.get_image). Fixing this requires also completing image v1
(proper find). Yeah, lots of tests are affected by that change.

Required-by: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650374
Change-Id: I709d8b48cb7867fd806e2f19781bb84739363843
(cherry picked from commit 63fe02bf770b47d6001ad802be851765f1d1b862)

commit_message:
Fix the conflict status with hacking.

The conflict is caused by:
    The user requested flake8 3.8.3 (from /home/zuul/.cache/pre-commit/repozi7hytk7)
    hacking 3.0.1 depends on flake8<3.8.0 and >=3.6.0

Install the latest version of hacking to fix the conflict error with the
pre-commit hook.

Change-Id: I8e8b0f56548b7f205ee9a55ff952782f81d845d8

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-18 11:21:13.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie6d229d1b2888220141aeb251ec75cfc9bd824de
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie6d229d1b2888220141aeb251ec75cfc9bd824de

Currently we define default values for *_driver parameters in
puppet-octavia but all of the default values are same as the defaults

commit_message:
Do not redefine default drivers

Currently we define default values for *_driver parameters in
puppet-octavia but all of the default values are same as the defaults
defined in Octavia itself.
Let's remove the default definition and use service default, to make
it easy to keep consistency with Octavia itself.

Change-Id: I521e8fedf09b25c7a8d6a5f2c67d04f586744bcd

with a different commit SHA.

commit_message:
Remove references to unsupported operating systems

All references to Gentoo, SUSE, Debian stretch and Centos-7  are removed.
Conditional tasks, ternary operators and variables are simplified where possible
OS specific variables files are generalised where possible

Change-Id: If9dfa6aaa1e90856c6a4c074fd33b8e49b57a5fc

commit_message:
[openstack] Create for all client and non-client lib wallaby branch

This creates the stable/wallaby branch for all client and non-client
libraries
now that we are past the lib freeze on March 11.

If a team wants to wait for a specific patch to make it to the library,
someone from the team can -1 the patch to have it held,or update that
patch with a different commit SHA.

Patches with no response will be merged by Friday, March 19.

Change-Id: I2109431db4f3de18e5ccbbe0d52f3952fb0b818e

commit_message:
pre-commit: Lower flake8 version

We're depending on flake8 3.8.3 and hacking>=3.0.1,<3.1.0, but that
version of hacking has a flake8<3.8.0 cap. Match our version of flake8
with the version expected by hacking. We can bump hacking later.

Change-Id: I3487f8ce92fdff4b0a33859cbdf37e1f1cbc37f1

and more timestamps in the sharded path, it actually wants to repair to

I know as it currently stands the repair doens't understand our

shows why we may need to think about adjusting the "weight" to take into
account our thresholds. As it shows that because of same object count
and more timestamps in the sharded path, it actually wants to repair to
a pre-sharded state, which would mean we'd need to shard it again.

I've gone added the weighted object count code I hacked together in the

Change-Id: I9919a9690db3d1682d36303b40226420bdd2c060

commit_message:
swift-manage-shard-ranges: sharded shard test + weighted object count

I know as it currently stands the repair doens't understand our
threshold limits for containers. But the test in this patch
shows why we may need to think about adjusting the "weight" to take into
account our thresholds. As it shows that because of same object count
and more timestamps in the sharded path, it actually wants to repair to
a pre-sharded state, which would mean we'd need to shard it again.

I've gone added the weighted object count code I hacked together in the
POC last year to see how it'll look.

Change-Id: I9919a9690db3d1682d36303b40226420bdd2c060

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removing specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.

The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

commit_message:
Add doc/requirements

We need to specify doc requirements in doc/requirements.txt
to avoid problems with the pip resolver [1] for the release team [2][3].
Removing specific doc requirements from test-requirements.txt.

The problem here is that this repos haven't doc/requirements.txt file
and by default in this case zuul will use the test-requirements.txt file
to pull requirements [4].

This requirements file contains extra requirements like flake8 that
collided with those allowed in our job environment and so the new pip
resolver fails to install these requirements and the job exits in error.

This project meet the conditions leading to the bug.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/release-job-failures/2021-January/001500.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019611.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019612.html
[4] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L36

Change-Id: Ie4cc84c7159f4b59be52439ef6e4c5e60474866d

commit_message:
Fix race condition with the object-store relation

The `CONFIGS.write(GLANCE_SWIFT_CONF)` is missing in the object-store
hook. This config file is used when the `swift` backend is enabled.

This bug is only encountered on some deployments, because there are multiple
places where `CONFIGS.write_all()` is called.

If the `object-store` relation is established, and another hook calls
`CONFIGS.write_all()`, this problem wouldn't reproduce. However, if
`object-store` relation is executed last, this issue will pop up.

Closes-Bug: #1915300
Change-Id: Ie52b18fc4dc637dbeec5ecfb8d5930a24c5f72cf

commit_message:
[tripleo]  Create for all client and non-client lib wallaby branch

This creates the stable/wallaby branch for all client and non-client
libraries
now that we are past the lib freeze on March 11.

If a team wants to wait for a specific patch to make it to the library,
someone from the team can -1 the patch to have it held,or update that
patch with a different commit SHA.

Patches with no response will be merged by Friday, March 19.

Change-Id: I4300048adf73738f6dad9e0c74d09baaaa25f304

commit_message:
Update Fundamental VNF LCM spec to correct a column name

Correct a column name in the vnf_lcm_filters table
described in "Data model impact",
because it is inconsistent with the attribute name
defined in ETSI NFV SOL 003[1].
  - vnfd_id --> vnfd_ids

[1] https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/NFV-SOL/001_099/003/02.06.01_60/gs_NFV-SOL003v020601p.pdf

Co-Authored-By: Yuichi Ishihara yuichi.ishihara.dx@hco.ntt.co.jp
Implements: blueprint support-fundamental-lcm
Change-Id: I52b8bd73c69de647f4dc4f9c9cf43e1329c4e3cc

[{'created': '2021-03-20 09:24:20.000000000', 'message': "Don't Create Neutron Router When Provider Network Is Used

'create_neutron_initial_network' function tries to create Neutron
router even when Q_USE_PROVIDER_NETWORKING is set to True.

This commit moves logic to create Neutron router, to prevent
creation of Neutron router when Q_USE_PROVIDER_NETWORKING is
set to True.

Closes-Bug: #1920586
Change-Id: I96e002460cb9097545967803562c8183406f0cec
"}]
commit_message:
Don't Create Neutron Router When Provider Network Is Used

'create_neutron_initial_network' function tries to create Neutron
router even when Q_USE_PROVIDER_NETWORKING is set to True.

This commit moves logic to create Neutron router, to prevent
creation of Neutron router when Q_USE_PROVIDER_NETWORKING is
set to True.

Closes-Bug: #1920586
Change-Id: I96e002460cb9097545967803562c8183406f0cec

[{'created': '2021-03-16 09:24:19.000000000', 'message': 'Resolve SADeprecationWarning for joinedload_all

Method joinedload_all was deprecated in SQLAlchemy in version 0.9.0 and
has been removed in version 1.4.0.

Standard way of fixing this is by replacing joinedload_all with a custom
method that chains joinedload calls for each word between ".".

In Cinder's case it's not even necessary, since all our joinedload_all
should have been joinedload in the first place.

This patch replaces joinedload_all with joinedload to resolve the
SADeprecationWarning issue and failure in newer releases.

Closes-Bug: #1832164
Change-Id: I50dc67b12764e6baa0ef05983242029b1f3d765b

commit_message:
Resolve SADeprecationWarning for joinedload_all

Method joinedload_all was deprecated in SQLAlchemy in version 0.9.0 and
has been removed in version 1.4.0.

Standard way of fixing this is by replacing joinedload_all with a custom
method that chains joinedload calls for each word between ".".

In Cinder's case it's not even necessary, since all our joinedload_all
should have been joinedload in the first place.

This patch replaces joinedload_all with joinedload to resolve the
SADeprecationWarning issue and failure in newer releases.

Closes-Bug: #1832164
Change-Id: I50dc67b12764e6baa0ef05983242029b1f3d765b

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-12-07 09:38:07.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Skip encryption metadata lookups if secret already exists on host

When connecting an encrypted volume to a host the _attach_encryptor
method will be called in order to either call a legacy os-brick
encryptor *or* configure a libvirt secret used by libvirt and QEMU to
natively decrypt LUKSv1 encrypted volumes. To create this libvirt secret
the configured key manager will be queried to provide and then decode
the associated secret before this is stashed within libvirt.

This change simply skips the above when an existing libvirt secret
associated with the target volume is found on the host already.

While this obviously optimises basic instance lifecycle flows such as a
simple power off and on it additionally resolves a more convoluted use
case when the ``[DEFAULT]/resume_guests_state_on_host_boot``
configurable is enabled. In this case the compute service has no request
context with which to query the key manager when attempting to restart
instances with encrypted volumes attached. As a result any attempt by
the compute service to restart an instance with an attached encrypted
volume would previously fail.

Closes-Bug: #1905701
Change-Id: Ia2007bc63ef09931ea0197cef29d6a5614ed821a
(cherry picked from commit a107a5099e86c3da80a6feeca6f840d5a3ad11b9)

commit_message:
libvirt: Skip encryption metadata lookups if secret already exists on host

When connecting an encrypted volume to a host the _attach_encryptor
method will be called in order to either call a legacy os-brick
encryptor *or* configure a libvirt secret used by libvirt and QEMU to
natively decrypt LUKSv1 encrypted volumes. To create this libvirt secret
the configured key manager will be queried to provide and then decode
the associated secret before this is stashed within libvirt.

This change simply skips the above when an existing libvirt secret
associated with the target volume is found on the host already.

While this obviously optimises basic instance lifecycle flows such as a
simple power off and on it additionally resolves a more convoluted use
case when the ``[DEFAULT]/resume_guests_state_on_host_boot``
configurable is enabled. In this case the compute service has no request
context with which to query the key manager when attempting to restart
instances with encrypted volumes attached. As a result any attempt by
the compute service to restart an instance with an attached encrypted
volume would previously fail.

Closes-Bug: #1905701
Change-Id: Ia2007bc63ef09931ea0197cef29d6a5614ed821a
(cherry picked from commit a107a5099e86c3da80a6feeca6f840d5a3ad11b9)

commit_message:
Reduce number of logs and disable ara HTML report

- Remove /var/log/kolla link to omit uploading the same logs twice
- Remove ARA HTML report (usually takes around 120MB) - can be easily
  generated from the sqlite db

Change-Id: I74cd6d1128689ab2c73f00ee08af3778d7d670a4
(cherry picked from commit 191b46ef40b5e33cf1581a89e8ce7ab699df44d8)

[{'created': '2021-03-17 13:51:53.000000000', 'message': 'doc: Remove cryptsetup reference for compute setup

Nova defaults to using the QEMU decryption layer
instead of cryptsetup now, and cryptsetup was never
needed on the compute for RBD encrypted volumes, so
this is not very useful advice.

Ref: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/523958

Change-Id: Ib158ffa9543fcbf5bf1cc8bfbd42e1ca766bfa30
'}]
commit_message:
doc: Remove cryptsetup reference for compute setup

Nova defaults to using the QEMU decryption layer
instead of cryptsetup now, and cryptsetup was never
needed on the compute for RBD encrypted volumes, so
this is not very useful advice.

Ref: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/523958

Change-Id: Ib158ffa9543fcbf5bf1cc8bfbd42e1ca766bfa30

subject: Fix name of ceilometer middleware package
messages:
[{'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2021-02-25 10:44:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29349, 'date': '2021-02-25 10:51:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2021-02-25 10:59:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

set package name in swift::params and use the $pyvers variable
$middleware_package_name = "python${pyvers}-ceilometermiddleware"

the class inherits swift class so you should get access to params in here

  package { 'python-ceilometermiddleware':
    ensure => $ensure,
    name   => $swift::params::middleware_package_name,
    tag    => ['openstack', 'swift-support-package'],
  }

otherwise this breaks the resource name, also, add release note and testing'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2021-02-25 12:48:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2021-02-25 13:02:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2021-02-25 16:24:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

missing testing and release note'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2021-02-27 09:20:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> $middleware_package_name = "python${pyvers}-ceilometermiddleware"

This was supposed to be done during the transition between Python 2 and Python 3. These days, OpenStack doesn't support Python 2 anymore, neither does all the distros that we support. So keeping the use of ${pyvers} makes absolutely no sense anymore.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-02-27 13:58:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> > $middleware_package_name = "python${pyvers}-ceilometermiddleware"
> 
> This was supposed to be done during the transition between Python 2 and Python 3. These days, OpenStack doesn't support Python 2 anymore, neither does all the distros that we support. So keeping the use of ${pyvers} makes absolutely no sense anymore.

I understand your point but I agree with Tobias and would suggest keeping consistency with existing codes. That helps us backport the fix to old branches if needed and deal with the future Python 4 (though I don't know when it actually happens).'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2021-02-28 11:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2021-02-28 11:03:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2021-02-28 11:18:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2021-02-28 14:16:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Fix name of ceilometer middleware package

This change fixes the package name of ceilometermiddleware and ensures
that proper name (python- or python3-) is used according to the default
python version.

Change-Id: I7c99aaf5f02b29a5901aee3e1d9f581079375f17

commit_message:
Add missed accel_uuids for _poll_shelved_instances

In [1], we are supporting shelve/unshelve the instance with accelerators
bonded, but we missed to deal the interval for polling shelved instances
to offload periodic task, so we should add the 'accel_uuids' support
in _poll_shelved_instances() periodic task.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/729563/

Co-Authored-By: Wenping Song <songwenping@inspur.com>

Closes-Bug: #1917592

Change-Id: I2ba69d0d727cc183f4a5dc52eaf4000962caeb4a

[{'created': '2021-02-11 19:35:28.000000000', 'message': 'Switch to new rolevar for run-temepst role

Tempest replaced the below rolevar for run-tempest role
- tempest_test_blacklist is replaced by tempest_test_exclude_list
- tempest_black_regex is replaced by tempest_exclude_regex

old name are still supported for compatiblity but we recommend
to switch to new one.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/774835
Change-Id: Ifef4ea2b43ce5462c119bdbd7a18703599066cc9
'}]
commit_message:
Switch to new rolevar for run-temepst role

Tempest replaced the below rolevar for run-tempest role
- tempest_test_blacklist is replaced by tempest_test_exclude_list
- tempest_black_regex is replaced by tempest_exclude_regex

old name are still supported for compatiblity but we recommend
to switch to new one.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/774835
Change-Id: Ifef4ea2b43ce5462c119bdbd7a18703599066cc9

This allows Designate to be used with PostgreSQL.

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-09 19:15:37.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: relinker: make cleanup a superset of relink

TODO:
  - see inline TODOs
  - check and test the cleanup vs no-cleanup branching logic
  - test all the stats collection and reporting
  - be more paranoid about removing files

The cleanup step can re-use all of the relink step and just
continue on to remove old files.

Collect stats for files linked and files removed.

Modify some of the logging messages.

Change-Id: I3d84a369d5e1d69193ca24fd3cccf28f734cc7cf
'}, {'created': '2021-03-10 15:26:51.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: relinker: make cleanup checks more robust

TODO:
  - see inline TODOs
  - check and test the cleanup vs no-cleanup branching logic
  - test all the stats collection and reporting
  - be more paranoid about removing files
  - add test for audit_location_generator yield_hash_dirs

In cleanup step, determine the most up to date set of files that
should be in the new partition directory and ensure that these all
exist before removing old file.

In relink step, use same logic to determine the most up to date set of
files that should be in the new partition directory and ensure that
links are created for all of those.

The cleanup step can then re-use all of the relink step and just
continue on to remove old files. The cleanup can therefore attempt to
create any links that it finds unexpectedly missing.

Collect stats for files linked and files removed.

Modify some of the logging messages.

Change-Id: I3d84a369d5e1d69193ca24fd3cccf28f734cc7cf

commit_message:
relinker: make relink step a subset of cleanup step

Use the same logic for determining which files need to be linked in
both the relink and cleanup steps.

Collect and log stats for files linked and files removed.

Modify some of the logging messages.

Change-Id: I3d84a369d5e1d69193ca24fd3cccf28f734cc7cf
